text: hey everybody thomas joseph here today
and i am super excited to share with you
one of my favorite things and not is
french fries and today i'm going to show
you the trick in making french fries at
home actually the real trick here is in
frying them twice now the kitchen
conundrum i would say is that most
people when they try to make them at
home they end up with something like
this an insipid french fry in color and
also kind of limp in texture
nobody wants a limp french fry here i'm
going to show you the perfect way to
make perfectly crisp on the outside but
tender on the inside french fries it's
all in the right potato for the job I
have a russet potato here and a russet
potato is great because it's high in
starch and it's low in moisture those
are the two good qualities that you need
for making french fries a Yukon Gold or
new potatoes they're low in starch and
high in moisture and you want to avoid
that moisture and oil they don't really
work together all we need to do is peel
the potato first now you can certainly
skip this step if you like that rustic
look I'm gonna be cutting my french
fries into a four inch length you could
certainly keep the ends of the potatoes
on you'll just have kind of an
inconsistent shape and that will alter
the cooking time so make sure that you
square off your potato now cut these
into about a third of an inch planks
these are thicker cut french fries now
you could certainly do a thinner cut
french fry but what that will yield you
in the end is a french fry that's kind
of crisp throughout I like the crisp
outside with more of a creamy interior
take your planks now and cut these into
a third of an inch pieces so they're
thick cut I would say they're a little
smaller than steak fries here but now
into a bowl of water and you might think
this is an odd step here but what it
does is it rinses off all of the extra
starch that is on the outside of the
potato so that when you do fry these
they don't
get too dark and burnt on the outside
before the inside is cooked so this step
really helps to give you that wonderful
color and also a crisp texture to your
french fries so this needs to sit in
your refrigerator for about 4 hours or
up to overnight so you could do this a
day in advance so I have a batch of
ranch fries that have been soaking
overnight here and you can see all the
starch has come out of the french fries
that now spread these out onto a sheet
tray or you could use a plate here lined
with a towel you need to dry them
thoroughly because any excess moisture
is going to pop up when you fry these so
as I dry these heat your oil and I'm
using a neutral oil like a safflower oil
you could use a canola oil anything that
will go to a high high heat to 300
degrees and 300 degrees is the blanching
temperature or the first cook for the
French fries we're going to cook them
until they're tender at a lower
temperature and then we're going to
increase the temperature to give that
crisp exterior my french fries are nice
and dry and I'm going to drop these into
the oil in stages you don't want to do
all of the fries at once because what
that is going to do is it's going to
bring the temperature of your oil down
to a very low temperature we want to
keep it in between two hundred and
eighty degrees and three hundred degrees
we're all set here and be very careful
here gently drop your potatoes into the
oil and whenever you're frying whenever
you're deep-frying like this make sure
that your pot isn't filled over halfway
because what happens whenever you add
your ingredient whether that french
fries like I'm making today if you were
doing fried chicken what happens is the
food that you put in displaces the oil
so it rises the level of the oil up and
also the bubbles can easily overflow if
your pot is filled with too much oil so
give the fries a little bit of a gentle
stir here and this will ensure that they
do not stick together and these are
going to cook at 300 degrees for about
three to four minutes and at three
minutes fish one of the fries out break
it in half and see
it's almost completely cooked in the
center if it is we know that that's
perfect and we're going to remove them
to a wire rack so it's been about three
minutes here I'm just gonna fish one of
the fries out to see if it is in fact
time to remove them from the Blanche
a knife cuts easily through so these are
ready to go fish them out and use one of
these large spiders they're called these
Asian style strainers they really help
to lift out french fries fried chicken
anything that you're frying in one piece
because they have that wide net so onto
a wire rack over a sheet tray here and I
like to use wire racks as opposed to a
paper towel-lined tray because I find
that whenever you play something
directly on paper towels they start to
steam french fries fried chicken the
bottom side starts to steam it doesn't
allow the air to kind of circulate
around and drain and dry in a nice
fashion so these are ready to go I'm
going to repeat the process with the
rest of my french fries and then we're
gonna be ready for it
the second fry my oil temperature is up
to 350 degrees and now we're ready for
the second fry and that gives that
wonderful color and that crisp golden
crunch on the outside of the french fry
can blanch them in advance up to four
hours before this final fry
use your fingers here because if you use
tongs you're going to break your french
fries into smaller pieces since they are
almost completely cooked you want to be
gentle with them so just give the fries
a little bit of a stir it's the same
thing here you want to agitate the fries
just a little bit so that they don't
stick together and now these will fry
for about four to five minutes until
they're a nice golden brown color and
the outside is crisp so it's been about
five minutes the fries are nice and
golden brown and again transfer them to
a wire rack to drain and cool slightly
but while they are hot you want to make
sure that you sprinkle them with some
fine sea salt now you could use regular
kosher salt here too I just like the
flavor
sea salt but there you have it I mean
french fries at home super simple all
you need to know is this two-step frying
technique and you'll be making french
fries at home all summer long
enjoy
